channel.title: Comments on: Fixing a SQL Server could not spawn FRunCM thread error
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: naseem
item.dc:creator: naseem
item.description: thank you! that worked for me

item.title: By: Rudy Ybarra
item.dc:creator: Rudy Ybarra
item.description:
Mukesh Sharma says: February 9, 2016 at 2:47 am The right answer Is double click on SQL services and go to log on option and run SQL Server on “Local System Account” than Re-Start SQL server successfully
This comment worked for me. I have two different sql instances 2012 & 2014, even after ensuring the ports were completely different for the instances it would still not start up until I changed the service account used.
item.content:encoded:
Mukesh Sharma says:
February 9, 2016 at 2:47 am
The right answer Is double click on SQL services and go to log on option and run SQL Server on “Local System Account” than Re-Start SQL server successfully

This comment worked for me. I have two different sql instances 2012 & 2014, even after ensuring the ports were completely different for the instances it would still not start up until I changed the service account used.

item.title: By: Samir Kazi
item.dc:creator: Samir Kazi
item.description:
I had the same issue... Check if there are multiple instances running on the server with the same port. I changed my port number to 1436 in SQL Server configuration settings ->Protocols for SQLService name and start the service.
I worked for me!!! Thanks....
item.content:encoded:
I had the same issue…
Check if there are multiple instances running on the server with the same port. I changed my port number to 1436 in SQL Server configuration settings ->Protocols for SQLService name and start the service.

I worked for me!!!
Thanks….

item.title: By: Mukesh Sharma
item.dc:creator: Mukesh Sharma
item.description: The right answer Is double click on SQL services and go to log on option and run SQL Server on "Local System Account" than Re-Start SQL server successfully
item.content:encoded: The right answer Is double click on SQL services and go to log on option and run SQL Server on “Local System Account” than Re-Start SQL server successfully

item.title: By: Tovero
item.dc:creator: Tovero
item.description: Try to delete files on the temp folder into C:\Users\#Username#\AppData\Local\Temp It's worked for me. Bye
item.content:encoded:
Try to delete files on the temp folder into C:\Users\#Username#\AppData\Local\Temp
It’s worked for me.
Bye

item.title: By: paresh motiwala
item.dc:creator: paresh motiwala
item.description: I could not delete any profiles on the node.
item.content:encoded: I could not delete any profiles on the node.
